1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-travel-idUSKCN11I05H	Clinton cancels California trip after pneumonia: aide	"
NEW YORK Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has canceled a campaign trip to California because of her diagnosis of pneumonia
column2: a campaign official said on Sunday.Clinton was scheduled to leave for California on Monday morning for a two-day swing that included fundraisers and a speech on the economy.

(Reporting by Amanda Becker

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-politics-hinckley-idUSKCN11G0S3	Would-be Reagan assassin released from psychiatric hospital	"
By Joseph Ax
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Would-be presidential assassin John Hinckley Jr. was released from a psychiatric hospital on Saturday
column2: media reports said
column3: 35 years after he shot U.S. President Ronald Reagan in an attack prompted by a deranged obsession with the actress Jodie Foster.Hinckley
column5: is moving in with his elderly mother in a gated community in Williamsburg
column6: Virginia
column7: where he has been making increasingly long furlough visits in recent years under the watchful eyes of the U.S. Secret Service.A federal judge in July ordered Hinckley's release from St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington
column8: finding that he no longer posed a danger to himself or to others. Hinckley was found not guilty by reason of insanity at a 1982 trial and was diagnosed with depression and psychosis
column9: both of which are now in remission
column12: reported that Hinckley was officially released from St. Elizabeth's on Saturday
column13: when he had been scheduled to be freed. A hospital employee who answered the phone on Saturday said she could not comment on patients to the media.Residents of the town have seemed largely unfazed by the prospect of Hinckley's release

column1: As a 25-year-old college dropout
column2: Hinckley had grown fixated upon Foster and the Martin Scorsese film ""Taxi Driver
column3: in which she played a teenage prostitute.Inspired by the film's main character
column4: who plots to kill a presidential candidate
column5: Hinckley opened fire on Reagan outside a Washington
column6: D.C.
column9: in a misguided effort to win Foster's affections.

column1: Reagan suffered a punctured lung but recovered quickly. His press secretary
column2: James Brady
column3: was left permanently disabled and eventually died of his injuries in 2014.The shooting left its mark in a number of ways. The Brady shooting helped launch the modern gun control movement
column4: and a 1993 bill named after him imposed background checks and a waiting period.Hinckley's verdict
column5: meanwhile
column6: led several states to rewrite their laws to make insanity defenses more difficult
column7: and the Secret Service toughened its security procedures following the assassination attempt.

column1: Hinckley's release has dozens of conditions attached
column2: including a requirement that he work or volunteer at least three days a week
column3: limit his travel
column4: allow law enforcement to track his movements and continue meeting with a psychiatrist.The Reagan family issued a statement in July strongly opposing Hinckley's release. Foster has declined to comment on Hinckley since 1981. (Reporting by Joseph Ax; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)"

column1: 3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN11G0KM	Trump closes in on Clinton's projected electoral lead: Reuters/Ipsos Poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Republican Donald Trump appears to have carved out a wider path to the White House as a number of states including Florida and Ohio are no longer considered likely wins for Democratic rival Hillary Clinton
column2: according to the latest Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project released on Saturday.The project
column3: which combines opinion polls with an analysis of voting patterns under different election scenarios
column4: still shows Clinton would have the best chance of winning the presidency if the Nov. 8 election were held today. Yet Trump has caught up to her level of support in several states.Clinton now has an 83 percent chance of winning the election by an average of 47 votes in the Electoral College
column5: the body that ultimately selects the president. In late August
column6: the States of the Nation estimated that Clinton had a 95 percent chance of winning by an average of 108 electoral votes.Over the past few weeks
column7: Clinton's lead in the national polls has slipped considerably. Polls tend to narrow as  Election Day nears
column8: and the Clinton campaign has struggled to overcome controversy about how she handled classified information while serving as secretary of state.

column1: A separate Reuters/Ipsos poll of likely voters showed an 8-point lead for Clinton has vanished since the last week of August.   Clinton is still favored to win 17 states
column2: including many with large
column3: urban populations such as New York
column4: New Jersey and California that heavily influence the outcome of the election. Trump would likely win 23 states
column5: many of them with smaller populations.The number of states projected for Clinton has dropped over the past few weeks. Two of those states
column6: Ohio and Florida
column7: were considered likely wins for Clinton in late August. Now the candidates are about even in support. Five more states
column8: including Michigan and North Carolina are also up for grabs.

column1: The sample size was insufficient to determine the outcome in Wyoming
column2: Vermont
column3: Alaska and the District of Columbia
column4: though Alaska usually votes Republican and Washington D.C. for the Democratic Party candidate.The Reuters/Ipsos States of the Nation project is driven by an online survey that gathers responses from about 15
column5: 000 people per week. Their responses are weighted according to the latest population estimates
column6: and each respondent is ranked according to their likelihood to vote.

column1: Once the poll is complete
column2: the project tallies the levels of support and estimated error for both candidates
column3: and then runs multiple election simulations given their respective support. (Click here: here for the project's interactive tool that allows users to set turnout targets for various voter groups.)    (Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Grant McCool)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN11F1ZO	Clinton
column2: Trump escalate fight in dramatic week on national security	"

column1: By Steve Holland and Jeff Mason
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK
WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Presidential candidates Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton clashed over national security again on Friday
column2: with Trump calling his Democratic rival ""trigger-happy"" and Clinton arguing his proposals would make the world a more dangerous place.The two White House hopefuls have waged a running battle this week over who is best placed to command the world's most powerful military
column3: with both touting their support from retired military leaders and attacking their opponent's temperament and judgment.Trump also injected drama into the national security debate this week by wholeheartedly endorsing Russian President Vladimir Putin as a strong leader who has fared better than U.S. President Barack Obama. Clinton
column4: many Democrats and even some in his own Republican party balked.  Trump
column5: speaking on Friday at the conservative Value Voters summit in Washington
column6: painted Clinton as a ""massive failure"" while she was America's top diplomat from 2009 to early 2013
column7: blaming her for the current turmoil in the Middle East.""The problem is
column8: Hillary Clinton is trigger-happy. Her tenure has brought us only war
column9: destruction and death. She's just too quick to intervene
column11: or to push for regime change
column12: he said at the summit.Meanwhile in New York
column13: Clinton met with national security and foreign policy experts who are supporting her campaign to discuss terrorism. She touted the bipartisan nature of the meeting and vowed to work across the aisle as president to tackle national security challenges.""The nominee on the other side promises to do things that will make us less safe
column14: Clinton told reporters at a news conference on Friday afternoon. ""National security experts on both sides of the aisle are chilled by what they're hearing from the Republican nominee.""Both candidates are hoping to capitalize on concerns about national security and paint their opponents as unqualified leading into the Nov. 8 presidential election.

column1: WORKING WITH THE RUSSIANS
Trump's speech on Friday comes after the candidate took the unusual step of criticizing U.S. policy in a program aired on Thursday night on Russian government-funded television network
column2: RT
column3: a 24-hour news channel that broadcasts in both English and Russian. He said he disagreed with the U.S. decision to invade Iraq in 2003 and that Obama botched the withdrawal.""It's a war we shouldn't have been in
column4: number one
column5: Trump said in the interview. ""And it's a war that
column6: when we got out
column7: we got out the wrong way. That's Obama.""Critics of the network
column8: which mostly targets audiences outside of Russia
column9: have described it as a propaganda arm of  Putin's government.

column1: American presidential candidates are not prone to condemn  their country before a foreign audience
column2: even if they are fierce critics of the current administration while campaigning in the United States. Trump has said far worse about Obama in appearances on U.S. television networks.Clinton blasted Trump for appearing on the network and praising Putin
column3: as he had done on Wednesday night during a televised national security forum. ""Every day that goes by this just becomes more and more of a reality television show
column4: Clinton said. ""It's not a serious presidential campaign
column5: and it is beyond one's imagination to have a candidate for president praising a Russian autocrat like Vladimir Putin.""The White House said it had no comment on Trump's remarks. The New York businessman also said on RT on Thursday he did not think Russia's government was behind the hack of Democratic National Committee email servers
column6: and doubted it was trying to interfere in the U.S. election. Experts inside and outside the government have pointed to Russian-backed actors as the source of the hack
column7: which has been used to leak information in an attempt to embarrass Democrats.

column1: Trump
column2: in his speech on Friday
column3: stuck to his belief that the United States and Russia can work together to defeat Islamic State militants. He said any nation that wants to join the United States against ISIS is welcome.""That includes Russia
column4: he said. ""If they want to join us in knocking out ISIS
column5: that's just fine as far as I'm concerned.""   Trump also sought on Friday to blame Clinton after reports that North Korea had tested a nuclear weapon
column6: arguing it was the fourth such test since the Democrat became secretary of state in 2009 and that she should have ended the nation's nuclear program before her tenure ended.""It's just one more massive failure from a failed secretary of state
column7: Trump said.Clinton called the North Korea test ""outrageous and unacceptable
column8: saying she supports imposing additional U.S. and United Nations sanctions.""It will be on the top of my list in dealing with China on how we're going to prevent what could very well be a serious conflict with North Korea
column9: she said. (Writing by Ginger Gibson.; Reporting by Steve Holland
column10: Doina Chiacu and Emily Stephenson in Washington and Jeff Mason in New York.; Editing by Richard Valdmanis and Mary Milliken)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN11G063	Clinton regrets calling 'half' of Trump supporters 'deplorable'	"
By Luciana Lopez and Jeff Mason
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Saturday said she regretted saying ""half"" of Republican rival Donald Trump's supporters belonged in a ""basket of deplorables
column2: but made no apologies for calling out ""prejudice and paranoia"" among Trump's campaign and supporters.""Last night I was 'grossly generalistic
column3: ' and that's never a good idea. I regret saying 'half' - that was wrong
column4: Clinton said in a statement
column5: the day after comments at a fundraiser in New York.But ""Trump has built his campaign largely on prejudice and paranoia
column6: she said
column7: adding: ""I won't stop calling out bigotry and racist rhetoric in this campaign.""Republicans and Trump supporters responded fiercely on social media to Clinton's remarks at the LGBT fundraiser and the episode threatened to distract from her efforts to paint Trump as unqualified for the presidency. But Trump on Saturday sought to use Clinton's comments to make the same charge about her.""How can she be President of our country when she has such contempt and disdain for so many great Americans?"" a Trump  statement asked.""Hillary Clinton should be ashamed of herself
column8: and this proves beyond a doubt that she is unfit and incapable to serve as President of the United States
column9: he added. At Friday night's fundraiser
column10: Clinton said Trump had given voice to hateful rhetoric through his behavior as a candidate for the White House in the Nov. 8 election. ""To just be grossly generalistic
column11: you can put half of Trump's supporters into what I call the 'basket of deplorables
column12: '"" Clinton said. ""Unfortunately there are people like that. And he has lifted them up."" Some of those were irredeemable
column14: but they did not represent America.The other basket of Trump's supporters constituted individuals desperate for change who felt let down by the government and the economy

column1: They don't buy everything he says
column2: but he seems to hold out some hope that their lives will be different
column3: Clinton said.  ""Those are people we have to understand and empathize with
column4: as well.""Trump's campaign hammered on Clinton throughout the day.""Hillary Clinton's low opinion of the people that support this campaign should be denounced in the strongest possible terms
column5: Mike Pence
column6: the governor of Indiana and Trump's running mate
column7: said at the Values Voter Summit in Washington.""So let me just say from the bottom of my heart: Hillary
column8: they are not a basket of anything. They are Americans
column10: a New York businessman who has never run for political office before
column11: regularly says things that some consider insulting
column12: racist or off-color. On Friday night
column15: that Clinton could shoot someone and not be prosecuted.""Because she's being so protected
column16: she could walk into this arena right now and shoot somebody with 20
column17: 000 people watching right smack in the middle of the heart and she wouldn't be prosecuted

column1: But Clinton's remarks got top billing on Twitter where the  hashtag #BasketOfDeplorables was trending
column2: with shows of  condemnation and support for Clinton.Twitter user Basketeer Vendetta
column3: under the account Vendetta92429
column4: tweeted a photo of Trump supporters wearing campaign T-shirts and hats
column5: adding: ""Proud to be part of the #BasketOfDeplorables with my fellow Americans.""And Trump himself tweeted: ""Wow
column6: Hillary Clinton was SO INSULTING to my supporters
column8: hard working people. I think it will cost her at the Polls!""But some Twitter users agreed with Clinton
column9: referencing  remarks by Trump that have been called racist
column10: such as when he described some Mexican immigrants drug dealers and rapists.RISKY COMMENT

column1: Clinton's comment could nevertheless end up being a boon to Trump.""As long as Trump stays out of the way and doesn't overshadow Hillary's comment
column2: her 'basket of deplorables' comment should dominate the media in the coming days and runs the risk of negatively defining her campaign
column3: said Republican strategist Doug Heye.Republican strategist Ana Navarro
column4: who has been highly critical of Trump
column5: said Clinton might have crossed an important line.""When you are running for President
column6: you are running to represent all Americans
column7: even the ones you think are deplorable
column10: said the remarks probably would not wrest voters from Clinton.""We're moving to the part of the election process where there's a lot less persuasion of new voters and more persuasion of the people who like you to turn out and work to elect you
column11: he added.Many of Clinton's fundraisers have been closed to the media
column12: but not the one on Friday night.  Some critics likened Clinton's observation to 2012 Republican candidate Mitt Romney's ""47 percent"" comment in which he said 47 percent of voters are dependent upon the government and would vote for President Barack Obama no matter what. His campaign struggled to recover after the remark leaked. But Democratic strategist Jim Manley
column14: pointed out that Romney was talking about all voters
column15: and Clinton was specifically describing Trump supporters. (Additional reporting by Steve Holland; Editing by Mary Milliken and Grant McCool)"

column1: 6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-arizona-idUSKCN11G04J	Democrats settle with Arizona officials in suit over primary voting problems	"

The Democratic National Committee on Friday said it settled part of a federal lawsuit over the actions of Arizona poll officials during the presidential primary that caused voters long waits and critics said disenfranchised some
column2: especially minorities.  The suit
column3: filed in April in U.S. District Court in Arizona
column4: targeted the decision to sharply cut polling locations in Maricopa County
column5: causing waits of up to five hours for those casting ballots during the March 22 primary.""This is a great victory for Arizonans
column6: and for our democracy
column8: interim chair of the Democratic National Committee
column9: said in a statement. ""We know that long lines depress turnout.""Representatives for the Maricopa County Board of Directors
column10: the Maricopa County Recorder's Office and the Secretary of State did not immediately respond to requests for comment.The election had been mired in controversy from the outset
column13: in a move that officials said was designed to cut costs.

column1: County officials were quick to take blame for the cuts
column2: saying they misjudged voter turnout
column3: based on recent history and increasing mail-in votes. Maricopa County miscalculated voter turnout and underestimated the number of vote centers needed for the March presidential primaries
column4: the Democratic National Committee said in the statement.

column1: As part of the settlement
column2: Maricopa County election officials agreed to consider the Democrats' recommendations on polling place queuing and the use of electronic management systems
column3: a copy of the agreement showed. The Democratic nominating contest for the Nov. 8 presidential election was won by Hillary Clinton over Bernie Sanders. Both their campaigns joined the lawsuit.

column1: The settlement has no bearing on other elements of the lawsuit
column2: such as a challenge to a law banning organizers from collecting mail-in ballots from a voter's home for delivery to polling locations. (Reporting by Eric M. Johnson in Seattle; Editing by Clarence Fernandez)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pence-idUSKCN11G00X	Trump campaign releases tax returns for Republican VP nominee Pence	"
WASHINGTON Donald Trump's Republican presidential campaign
column2: widely criticized for refusing to release the candidate's tax returns
column3: released 10 years of returns on Friday for vice presidential nominee Mike Pence.The Trump campaign also repeated a pledge that Trump would release his own returns once the government completes an audit.Pence's returns for 2006 to 2015 showed the Indiana governor and former U.S. congressman paid an effective tax rate that ranged from 10 percent to 16.5 percent.""These returns are being released with the full support of Mr. Trump who plans to release his tax returns upon completion of a routine audit
column4: the campaign said.Disclosure of tax returns is a standard procedure for all modern presidential candidates. Trump's critics
column5: including the campaign of Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column6: have suggested he may be hiding something.

column1: Some have speculated that Trump may pay little or no tax or that his net worth may be much less than the $10 billion he has claimed. Pence and his wife
column2: Karen
column3: reported adjusted gross income over the 10 years ranging from about $113
column4: 000 last year to over $187
column6: while the effective state and federal tax rate ranged from a low of just over 10 percent in 2013 to a high of 16.5 percent in 2014
